title: Jeff Stelling demands to be called 'El Presidente' by Matt Le Tiss
text:
1 comment 
Hampshire Sky Sports presenter Jeff Stelling has ordered the ex-players on his TV show to call him ‘El Presidente’ from now on. 
The 60-year-old is thrilled to have been appointed honorary president of his home town football club Hartlepool United. 
But the broadcaster, who lives in Bishop’s Waltham, is expecting some stick about his new role from the likes of Matt Le Tissier and Charlie Nicholas who sit alongside him in the TV studio on match days. 
He said: “I’m sure they will tease me – it’s OK as long as they call me El Presidente.” 
Jeff has supported the League two team since he was eight. 
But he fears not all the Hartlepool’s fans will be happy he is the club’s new signing. 
He added: “I bet most supporters would rather a new centre-half or midfielder or striker rather than a short, fat club president.” 
Jeff, whose dad was a steelworker, grew up in a Hartlepool council house, sharing his bedroom with two brothers. 
He said: “I’ve had so much good fortune in my life and this is just another impossible dream achieved. 
“When you are watching as a kid your dream is to play for the team but I was never going to be good enough for that. 
“Something like this would never cross your mind.” 
He still remembers being taken to his first Hartlepool match as a boy. 
“I was eight and I’m pretty sure it was Hartlepool against Workington. I think we won 3-1 and I thought ‘fantastic, it must always be like this’ and then we didn’t win for the next 20 games.” 
Jeff, who has presented the Sky show for 20 years, said he is prepared to do anything to help the team. 
He said: “I’ll be as active as they want me to be. Anything I can do to promote the club I’m happy to do so.” Share article 
The father-of-three also said he struggles to contain his excitement whenever Hartlepool goal flashes up on the vidiprinter. 
During the 2008-09 season he used a toy doll of American soul singer James Brown that sang ‘I feel good’ whenever his team scored a goal.
